Issues.Title: The library uses environment variables to package an error
Issues.Body:
Hello, I use environment variables in my angular library. When packaging this library, it says "File'C:/Test/src/environments/environment.ts' is not under'rootDir''C:\Test\projects\x -shared\src'.''C:\Test\projects\x-shared\src'.'rootDir' is expected to contain all source files.". I want to know why and how to use environment in angular library?

Thank you!

Issues.Title: fix(common): encode url reserved characters
Issues.Body:
Previously, if a http param's value contains reserved characters such as
";", the value is not encoded correctly. It was encoded and then replaced.

According to RFC3986[ https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3986#page-11]( https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3986#page-11), the
reserved characters should be percent-encoded before the url is formed.

"URIs include components and subcomponents that are delimited by
characters in the "reserved" set.  These characters are called
"reserved" because they may (or may not) be defined as delimiters by
the generic syntax, by each scheme-specific syntax, or by the
implementation-specific syntax of a URI's dereferencing algorithm.
If data for a URI component would conflict with a reserved
character's purpose as a delimiter, then the conflicting data must be
percent-encoded before the URI is formed. "

reserved    = gen-delims / sub-delims

gen-delims  = ":" / "/" / "?" / "#" / "[" / "]" / "@"

sub-delims  = "!" / "$" / "&" / "'" / "(" / ")"
          / "*" / "+" / "," / ";" / "="

This commit fixes this by removing the replace function.

## What is the current behavior?
The reserved characters in http param values are not encoded. So when i pass   a=123;xx  ,  i got {"a": "123", "xx": ""} 

Issue Number: N/A


## What is the new behavior?
All the reserved characters will be encoded to avoid conflicts.

Issues.Title: fix(compiler): include parenthesis in expression source spans
Issues.Body:
The parser does not include parenthesis in the AST, so if a LHS
expression would be parenthesized then its start span would start
after the opening parenthesis. Previously, some parent AST nodes would
be created with the start span of its LHS as its own start, so this
resulted in the parent AST node not encompassing the opening parenthesis
in its source span. This commit fixes the issue by capturing the start
index prior to parsing a child AST tree, which is then used as the
start of the source span of the the parent AST node that is parsed.

Fixes #40721
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(compiler): include parenthesis in expression source spans" (#40740)

Issues.Title: refactor(compiler-cli): remove event output helper from TCB
Issues.Body:
In 5c547675b11a24b16c20df1718583a0e7ed49cbd the `EventEmitter.subscribe`
API was extended with a new signature that allows the emitter's generic
type `T` to flow into the subscribe callback. This new signature removes
the need for the special `_outputHelper` function that used to be
emitted into TCBs when `strictOutputEventTypes`/`strictTemplates` is
enabled.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(compiler-cli): remove event output helper from TCB" (#40738)

Issues.Title: fix(docs-infra): correctly handle entry-points with no public exports
Issues.Body:
Previously, if an entry-point had no public exports (such as the `@angular/platform-server/shims` introduced in #40559, which is a side-effect-ful entry-point), it was incorrectly marked as having all its exports deprecated (which marks the entry-point as deprecated as well).

This commit fixes this by ensuring that an entry-point is not marked as having all its exports deprecated if it has no public exports.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(docs-infra): correctly handle entry-points with no public exports" (#40737)

Issues.Title: JIT compiler throws an error on Samsung Internet Browser
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report

### Affected Package

The issue is caused by package @angular/core, version 11.1.2 and probably some older versions.

### Is this a regression?

This used to work, but we are not able to exactly pinpoint (yet) the first version where this started to be an issue.

### Description

We are using Angular JIT compiler in production to compile and render HTML that is dynamically added during the runtime. Even though this is related to compilation process, we have isolated an error to be in @angular/core package.

Problem is manifesting itself only on Samsung Internet browser. We are currently using latest version 13.2.1.70.

All our web applications are currently crashing during the Angular bootstrap process as you can see in the following log:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/34662138/107117516-07705300-687b-11eb-9ffb-97ab0be582fb.png)

This log was collected on Chrome desktop version by attaching to Samsung Internet browser on Samsung Galaxy S7.

Further inspection of minified code shows that error is originating from the following line:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/34662138/107117537-27077b80-687b-11eb-881d-4cdd3f553ada.png)

We have isolated this portion of code on Angular code base for versions 11.1.x:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/34662138/107117542-3686c480-687b-11eb-88f6-429bfe0d2da5.png)

This code extract is from trusted_types.ts file in core/src/util/security folder.

Applications are tested and working on Safari, Chrome and Firefox. It is Samsung Internet browser that has an issue with this. We have tried multiple devices with Samsung Internet, results are the same.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "JIT compiler throws an error on Samsung Internet Browser" (#40733)

Issues.Title: feat(animations): add support for disabling animations through BrowserAnimationsModule.forRoot
Issues.Body: Currently the only way to disable animations is by providing the `NoopAnimationsModule` which doesn't allow for it to be disabled based on runtime information. These changes add support for disabling animations based on runtime information by using `BrowserAnimationsModule.forRoot({disableAnimations: true})`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(animations): add support for disabling animations through BrowserAnimationsModule.forRoot" (#40731)

Issues.Title: Provide usage examples for APP_INITIALIZER token
Issues.Body:
Currently the pages that refer to `` and `` symbols don't contain examples of how `APP_INITIALIZER` can be used, see:

- https://angular.io/api/core/ApplicationInitStatus
- https://angular.io/api/core/APP_INITIALIZER

If there are some examples in guides that I missed, it'd be great to add links to the mentioned doc pages.

Note: it makes sense to update docs once PR #33222 lands, since it adds support for `Observable`s as well (so we can have both Promise and Observable-based examples).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Provide usage examples for APP_INITIALIZER token" (#40730)

Issues.Title: More precise type for APP_INITIALIZER token
Issues.Body:
Currently the `APP_INITIALIZER` token is typed as:

https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/d067dc0cb9a3088a7c3443d33d35f7a0856b8a49/packages/core/src/application_init.ts#L31

The type should be more precise and contain actual type that Angular handles, something like:

```
export const APP_INITIALIZER = new InjectionToken<Array<() => Promise<unknown>>>('Application Initializer');
```

Note:

- this would be a breaking change
- it makes sense to implement this after PR #33222 lands, since it'd introduce `Observable` support as well
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "More precise type for APP_INITIALIZER token" (#40729)

Issues.Title: Optimizing incremental compilation status tracker
Issues.Body:
This issue is created as a status tracker to implement an optimization for incremental compilations to enable more effective reuse of work from the previous compilation. The general idea is that decorated classes will be compared to their equivalent in the prior compilation and skip emit if nothing relevant has changed. There has been a working prototype in #39791 which implements this idea, which has since been refined to a simplified yet more effective approach.

This work aims to address #34867 and #40635. One initial improvement in response to #40635 is pending in  angular/angular-cli#19986 which avoids an inefficiency in Webpack's dependency mechanism resulting in a significant improvement of rebuild times. This work should take this one step further and avoid emit of files when their generated output could not possibly be affected by the change.

- [x] Implement semantic dependency graph and symbol comparison ([ngtsc/semantic-updates](https://github.com/angular/angular/tree/ngtsc/semantic-updates))
- [ ] Test various scenarios:
  - [ ] Update expectations for existing tests.
  - [ ] Test behavior in combination with errors in the program.
  - [ ] Test behavior in combination with external declarations.
  - [ ] Components without an NgModule that are then declared into an NgModule, and vice versa.
  - [ ] Components that are moved from one NgModule to another.
  - [ ] Changing an NgModule into a Component, and all other relevant combinations.
  - [ ] Introducing and breaking cyclic component includes to verify remote scoping.
  - [ ] Behavior of classes declared inside functions
  - [ ] Classes that are exported under a different name
- [ ] Update incremental rebuild documentation.
- [ ] Review
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Optimizing incremental compilation status tracker" (#40728)

Issues.Title: Angular Elements not working during SSR in Angular 11
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package `@angular/elements` ### Is this a regression? Yes, this used to work in Angular 8-10. ### Description During **SSR**, custom elements are getting default values on `@Input()` overridden by `undefined`. For example, if you have a component as follows: ``` class MyComponent { @Input() myInput = 'default value'; } ``` And you create an element `my-element` and use it without the `my-input` attribute (``), then it will set `myInput = undefined` rather than `'default value'`. I tracked it down to this statement in the elements strategy where the inputs are initialized: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/bdce769/packages/elements/src/component-factory-strategy.ts#L212 If I provide a fallback when the map does not contain the input value, then everything works again. ``` this.setInputValue( propName, this.initialInputValues.get(propName) ?? // fallback to component class property this.componentRef.instance[propName] ); ``` ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://github.com/jaysoo/ng-elements-ssr ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:**

Issues.Title: fix(localize): improve invalid syntax in extraction error message
Issues.Body:
This will partially resolve https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/40702#issuecomment-773307996 but we also need a change in the CLI code too.

Previously if the code is invalid the error message might look like:

```
Unexpected messageParts for `$localize` (expected an array of strings).
```

This is not very helpful for debugging where the problem occurs.

Now we build a "code-frame" description to give more useful information:

```
TypeError: Cannot create property 'message' on string '.../src/app/app.component.js:
Unexpected messageParts for `$localize` (expected an array of strings).
  4 | export class AppComponent {
  5 |     constructor() {
> 6 |         this.title = $localize(a = ['myapp'], []);
    |                                ^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  7 |     }
  8 | }
  ```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(localize): improve invalid syntax in extraction error message" (#40724)

Issues.Title: @angular/compiler parseTemplate() missing leading paren in parsed source
Issues.Body:

# üêû bug report

### Affected Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages as the source of the bug? -->
The issue is caused by package @angular/compiler

### Is this a regression?

<!-- Did this behavior use to work in the previous version? -->
I have gone as far back at 10.1.4 and this issue is there, so not sure it was ever correct...

### Description

For source such as:

```html
<div *ngIf="(foo | async) == false">
```

or

```html
{{ (foo | async) == false }}
```

parsing them with `parseTemplate()` (with `{ preserveWhitespaces: true, preserveLineEndings: true }`) produces location information which is incorrect because the "source" in the AST is missing the leading parenthesis.

E.g. for the first example the `*ngIf` "value" `ASTWithSource` "source" is `"foo | async) == false"`


## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction
As described above for the latest compiler version.

The version on astexplorer is the outdated `10.1.4` version I mentioned but you can also reproduce the issue there: https://astexplorer.net/#/gist/80da9069b97ab6e5c288eca9198b65eb/48a76cfc471b7fedca15e12774bbea3798f8d3f4

<!--
If StackBlitz is not suitable for reproduction of your issue, please create a minimal GitHub repository with the reproduction of the issue.
A good way to make a minimal reproduction is to create a new app via `ng new repro-app` and add the minimum possible code to show the problem.
Share the link to the repo below along with step-by-step instructions to reproduce the problem, as well as expected and actual behavior.

Issues that don't have enough info and can't be reproduced will be closed.

You can read more about issue submission guidelines here: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#-submitting-an-issue
-->

------

**We are currently having to work around this in angular-eslint by manually adjusting the start location by 1.**

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): fixed ignoring of karma plugins config
Issues.Body:
In angular 11 Previously `karma-coverage` was validated only when in karma plugins config one of these was added
``'karma-coverage'` or `require('karma-coverage')`

This change will allow cli to validate `karma-coverage` plugin if in `karma.conf.js` `'karma-*'` is used. Example:
```
plugins: [
      ...
      'karma-*',
      require('@angular-devkit/build-angular/plugins/karma'),
      ...
    ]
```

Fixes #19993
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): fixed ignoring of karma plugins config" (#19994)

Issues.Title: Angular v11 ignores karma plugin config `karma-*` and throws error
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [x] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [x] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] extract-i18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? `karma-coverage` was made required in angular 11 and strict checking of `karma-coverage` was also introduced in v11. So, no it is not a regression ### Description According to https://karma-runner.github.io/6.1/config/configuration-file.html > List of plugins to load. A plugin can be a string (in which case it will be required by Karma) or an inlined plugin - Object. By default, Karma loads all sibling NPM modules which have a name starting with karma-*. I have added `karma-coverage` in `package.json` and installed it and added `karma-*` to the plugins config in `karma.conf.js` Angular cli ignores the installed package as it seems `karma-*` config is ignored while validating `karma-coverage` is installed It works when in plugins configuration one of these is added `'karma-coverage'` or `require('karma-coverage')` ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction 1. Add `karma-coverage` in `package.json` and install it (`npm install`) ``` "karma-coverage": "^2.0.3", ``` 2. Add `'karma-*'` in `karma.conf.js` . Example: ``` plugins: [ 'karma-*', require('@angular-devkit/build-angular/plugins/karma'), ] ``` 3. Run tests `ng test` ## üî• Exception or Error 


 ERROR [karma-server]: Server start failed on port 9876: Error: karma-coverage must be installed in order to run code coverage.

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/sass-loader/compare/v10.1.1...v11.0.0)

##### Notes

-   using `~` is deprecated and can be removed from your code (**we recommend it**), but we still support it for historical reasons. 

Why you can removed it?
The loader will first try to resolve `@import`/`@use` as relative, if it cannot be resolved, the loader will try to resolve `@import`/`@use` inside [`node_modules`](https://webpack.js.org/configuration/resolve/#resolve-modules).

##### ‚ö† BREAKING CHANGES

-   minimum supported `webpack` version is `5`

##### Features

-   supported the [`resolve.byDependency`](https://webpack.js.org/configuration/resolve/#resolvebydependency) option, you can setup `{ resolve: { byDependency: { sass: { mainFiles: ['custom', '...'] } } } }`

##### [10.1.1](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/sass-loader/compare/v10.1.0...v10.1.1) (2021-01-11)

##### Bug Fixes

-   problem with resolving and the `includePaths` option ([#​913](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/sass-loader/issues/913)) ([cadc75e](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/sass-loader/commit/cadc75e80caf7d32ea47de1cbaab639f9204c0eb))

Issues.Title: fix(@ngtools/webpack): reduce overhead of Angular compiler rebuild requests
Issues.Body: This change adds additional checks to reduce the number of Webpack `rebuildModule` calls when the Angular compiler requests additional files to be rebuilt. Now if an emitted file's output does not change from its previous emit, a Webpack rebuild of the module is not performed. This can greatly reduce the amount of computation needed during a rebuild as any files that required re-analysis by the Angular compiler but whose final output did not change will not trigger potential expensive Webpack module graph analysis and additonal module rebuilds.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(@ngtools/webpack): reduce overhead of Angular compiler rebuild requests" (#19986)

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): display the code-frame for localization errors
Issues.Body:
Previously if there was an error processing the AST in the Babel plugin that does
the replacement of i18n messages, the error shown did not provide much help
in where in the code the problem appears.

Now we display a "code-frame" representation of the position in the parsed
source-code where the AST processing failed.

Partially resolves https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/40702#issuecomment-773307996
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): display the code-frame for localization errors" (#19982)

With this change we add `postcss-preset-env` with stage 3 features. This stage includes support for:

 - all property
 - break properties
 - custom properties
 - font-variant property
 - gap properties
 - media query ranges

See https://preset-env.cssdb.org/features#stage-3
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): add `postcss-preset-env` with stage 3 features" (#19980)

# üöÄ Feature request


<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
- [X] new
- [X] build
- [X] serve
- [X] test
- [X] e2e
- [X] generate
- [X] add
- [X] update
- [X] lint
- [X] extract-i18n
- [X] run
- [X] config
- [X] help
- [X] version
- [X] doc

### Description

To prevent [issues](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/19957) [like](https://github.com/ionic-team/angular-toolkit/issues/250) [this](https://github.com/ionic-team/angular-toolkit/issues/437) it would be great if the `@angular-devkit` libs follow the same semantic versioning as the main `@angular` packages.

### Describe the solution you'd like

So e.g. instead of releasing the next major version as `@angular-devkit/architect@0.1200.0` to release it as `@angular-devkit/architect@12.0.0`

This way semver checks will mork more reliably throughout the angular community.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

NOTE: I have tried to search for existing open issues that describe the same feature request. Didn't find one. I'll be gladly closing this issue for another one if you could just point me in the right direction.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Promoting @angular-devkit packages to stable semver" (#19978)

Issues.Title: test(@angular/cli): allow invalid deps E2E to pass on release commits
Issues.Body: When installing an outdated version of `@schematics/angular`, the package manager will also analyze installed dependencies.  In the case of a release commit those dependencies are not yet on the npm registry and the outdated package install will fail. To remedy this situation, the outdated package and its two dependencies are published to the local test registry which allows the unreleased versions of the tooling packages to also be available to the package manager.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "test(@angular/cli): allow invalid deps E2E to pass on release commits" (#19967)

Issues.Title: bug(mat-drawer, mat-vertical-stepper): Closed drawer content accessible with tab key
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

https://stackblitz.com/edit/drawer-stepper?file=src/app/sidenav-autosize-example.html

Note: use preview in a new window to avoid interaction with stackblitz editor using tab key - https://drawer-stepper.stackblitz.io/

Steps to reproduce:
1. Use **position=end** on mat-drawer (not reproducible with position=start)
2. Put a vertical **stepper** within a drawer
3. Add some **focusable element** within a step (e.g. button, input...)
4. Use **tab key** to focus and scroll to an element although the drawer is closed
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

Content of a closed drawer shouldn't be reachable via tab key.


#### Actual Behavior

Using tab key, an element can be focused and viewed, although it is contained within a closed drawer.


#### Environment

- Angular: 11.1.1
- CDK/Material: 11.1.1
- Browser(s): Chrome, Firefox
- Operating System: macOS, Ubuntu
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(mat-drawer, mat-vertical-stepper): Closed drawer content accessible with tab key" (#21831)

Issues.Title: feat(cdk/drag-drop): allow for preview container to be customized
Issues.Body:
Currently we always insert the drag preview at the `body`, because it allows us to avoid dealing with `overflow` and `z-index`. The problem is that it doesn't allow the preview to retain its inherited styles.

These changes add a new input which allows the consumer to configure the place into which the preview will be inserted.

Fixes #13288.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(cdk/drag-drop): allow for preview container to be customized" (#21830)

Issues.Title: fix(cdk/drag-drop): destroyed items not being cleaned up correctly
Issues.Body:
Fixes a memory leak in `CdkDrag` which prevented it from being cleaned up. The problem is that we keep track of all the instances in an array, but there was a typo in the cleanup logic which meant that the items would never be removed from the array.

Fixes #21818.

Issues.Title: bug(TABS): Tab panel content not accessible to multiple screen readers
Issues.Body:
The [WAI-ARIA Example of Tabs with Manual Activation](https://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria-practices/examples/tabs/tabs-2/tabs.html) puts a tabindex="0" on the tab panel to put it in the page tab sequence to facilitate movement to panel content for assistive technology users. 

Adding tabindex="0" to the mat-tab-body which has the role="tabpanel" attribute would bring the Angular material tabs more in line with the WAI-ARIA authoring practices and "facilitate movement to panel content for assistive technology users".

#### Reproduction

You can see the behavior in the official Stackblitz example: https://stackblitz.com/angular/mgokvrvonpe?file=src/app/tab-group-basic-example.ts

Steps to reproduce:
1. Load Stackblitz example
2. Start a screen reader: JAWS, NVDA or VoiceOver
3. Activate new tab using keyboard
4. Try to navigate to the tab panel so the screen reader can read the content 
 
#### Expected Behavior

A screen reader user should be able to navigate to the tab panel content so it can be read aloud by the screen reader.

#### Actual Behavior

NVDA and VoiceOver are not able to read the tab panel content. 

JAWS provides instructions to use JAWS key + ALT + M to switch to the controlled element, which allows the user to read the tab panel content. But NVDA and VoiceOver don't appear to provide a similar keyboard shortcut.

#### Environment

- Angular: All
- CDK/Material: All
- Browser(s): All
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): All
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(TABS): Tab panel content not accessible to multiple screen readers" (#21819)

Issues.Title: CDK Platform: Platform should have classification for browsers used on MacOS
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

Platform should classify MacOS based browsers. The current feature lacks MacOs detection. Additional flag required MACOS:true

#### Use Case

Open Angular App on macOS Chrome or Safari. The following output log is for Platform on MacOS chrome

ANDROID: false
BLINK: true
EDGE: false
FIREFOX: false
IOS: false
SAFARI: false
TRIDENT: false
WEBKIT: false
isBrowser: true

#### Expected Feature:

ANDROID: false
BLINK: true
EDGE: false
FIREFOX: false
IOS: false
**MACOS:true**
SAFARI: false
TRIDENT: false
WEBKIT: false
isBrowser: true
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "CDK Platform: Platform should have classification for browsers used on MacOS" (#21815)

Issues.Title: feat(DASHBOARD): TITLE  Enhance the Schematic to generate widgets with settings and a base class
Issues.Body:
#### The current Dashboard schematic should be enhanced with a better change/aggregator pattern, _such that_ the `contained ` widgets collection have some `base `common functionality.

#### Use Case
Hello, this is a request to enhance the Dashboard Schematic Generation.

Since business mostly use dashboards for reporting fragments of information\visuals\charts\tables across the organization and always house that data inside widgets; these widgets always contain _common basic_ plumbing that could be placed in a base class. However, that base is missing, if you could please enhance the Dashboard Schematic _**it would greatly benefit the developer community if a strategy/pattern was used in the dashboard component**_. These reports are data housed inside widgets form of charts, maps, tables etc.  However, in this schematic there is no UI aggregation, or common base settings.

**Dashboard**

- [ ] Typical dashboard is One (or many pages/tabs)
- [ ] Each Dashboard houses widgets/containers
- [ ] Be able to share change strategy with their contained widgets and other tabs
- [ ] DI` @Injectable` Service to accept new or remove old widgets

**Widgets** -

- [ ] Each of the widgets should extend from a base class
- [ ] The widget should share/exchange some common data with other widgets
- [ ] Widgets should have settings (an Icon gear, that can be extend, `Print, Copy, Export, Import, Refresh` etc.)
- [ ] Some lifecycle that allows them to clean up or change within that dashboards context


![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21086190/106939093-cd257b00-66ed-11eb-877b-39b80cd33f25.png)

Some places have layed out information on this, because it was lacking.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21086190/106939914-e2e77000-66ee-11eb-869a-ddb8fddf659f.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "feat(DASHBOARD): TITLE  Enhance the Schematic to generate widgets with settings and a base class" (#21808)

Issues.Title: fix(material/dialog): focus restoration not working inside shadow dom
Issues.Body: Related to #21796. The dialog focus restoration works by grabbing `document.activeElement` before the dialog is opened and restoring focus to the element on destroy.  This won't work if the element is inside the shadow DOM, because the browser will return the shadow root. These changes add a workaround.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(material/dialog): focus restoration not working inside shadow dom" (#21811)
